title: 110_hr392
content: The Act is titled the "District of Columbia and United States Territories Circulating Quarter Dollar Program Act" and involves the issuance of redesigned quarter dollars honoring the District of Columbia and each of the territories. Section 5112 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include a new subsection for the redesign and issuance of circulating quarter dollars honoring the District of Columbia and the territories in 2009. The Secretary has flexibility in selecting designs emblematic of these locations for the coins. The Secretary has the authority to choose designs for quarter dollars issued in 2009, with specific inscriptions on the reverse and obverse sides. The designs will represent the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, and American territories. The Secretary will select designs for quarter dollars representing the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the United States Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands after consultation with relevant officials. The Secretary may designate designs for quarter dollars representing the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the United States Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. Designs can be submitted through a selection and approval process developed by the Secretary, with participation from various officials, artists, engravers, and Mint members. The Secretary may designate designs for quarter dollars representing various territories, with input from officials, artists, engravers, and Mint members. The designs must meet standards of dignity and cannot include portraits of living or deceased individuals. The Secretary may mint and issue quarter dollars with designs representing territories, following standards of dignity and excluding portraits of living or deceased individuals. The coins minted shall be considered numismatic items and may be issued in uncirculated, proof, or silver qualities. The Secretary may mint quarter dollars with designs representing territories in 2009, in a specific order, with a composition of 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper. If the District of Columbia or any territory becomes a state before the 10-year period ends, certain provisions will apply. If a territory becomes a state before the 10-year period ends, specific provisions will apply. If a territory becomes independent before quarter dollars are minted with designs emblematic of that territory, this subsection will no longer apply to that territory. The term 'territory' includes Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the US Virgin Islands, and the Northern Mariana Islands. The House of Representatives passed the bill on January 23, 2007. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
